Safety factor of 1.1 is very uncommon in rocketry, 1.25 is a good default. Some parts go higher, and you realllllly need to prove why you are going below 1.25. I was surprised when my professor who worked at NASA and other private companies told us that

1:14:24 Tim deleted his explanation.
Max q
q defined as "dynamic pressure" q = rho × 1/2 × V²
This is the point, where the math expression: q = ambient air density times 1/2 times true airspeed squared is maximum.
The speed increases, but the density decreases much faster, and q reaches a maximum.
aerodynamically, q is the reference, used to calculate the aerodynamic forces and moments. Only at low speeds is q equal to the stagnation pressure at the nose of the starliner. This is only an aproximation during transonic and supersonic speed.

Tim I certainly don't want anything to 'go wrong' and technological diversity is arguably synonymous with redundancy.

However the booster involved is basically single use and consuming a substantial quantity of obsolete components left over from the days of the Space Shuttle.

If, doing so would result in much cheaper launches, even if only until all those old parts were used up, that would be ample justification for sustaining Starliner and ULA until then.

But it makes absolutely no economic sense to claim justification for persisting with refinement of obsolete technologies if missions employing them are projected to be tens, of millions, of US dollars more expensive than any already offered or soon to be offered by other ventures.

Redundancy and healthy stimulus to technological development and refinement is engendered by competition and highly desirable, but surely it is not, if subject to persistently uncompetitive circumstances?
